title: Provides for apportionment of state monies to nonpublic schools for the cost of asbestos inspections
summary: Provides for an additional apportionment of state monies to nonpublic schools for the cost of asbestos inspections for school years beginning on and after July 1, 2011.

       AN ACT to amend chapter 507 of the laws of 1974, relating  to  providing

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Chapter 507 of the laws of 1974, relating to providing  for
    2  the  apportionment  of state monies for nonpublic schools, is amended by
    3  adding a new section 3-a to read as follows:
    4    S 3-A. ADDITIONAL APPORTIONMENT.  IN  ADDITION  TO  THE  APPORTIONMENT
    5  PROVIDED  FOR IN SECTION THREE OF THIS ACT, THE COMMISSIONER SHALL ANNU-
    6  ALLY APPORTION TO EACH QUALIFYING SCHOOL, FOR SCHOOL YEARS BEGINNING  ON
    7  AND  AFTER JULY 1, 2011, AN AMOUNT EQUAL TO THE ACTUAL COSTS INCURRED BY
    8  EACH SUCH SCHOOL DURING THE PRECEDING SCHOOL YEAR INSPECTIONS TO  DETER-
    9  MINE THE EXISTENCE OF ASBESTOS IN SUCH SCHOOLS.
   10    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2263

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend chapter 507 of the laws of 1974, relating to providing for
the apportionment of state monies for nonpublic schools, in
relation to providing for an additional apportionment for asbestos
inspections

SUMMARY:
This bill would amend chapter 507 of the
laws of 1974 to
provide that non-public schools are reimbursed for administrative
costs incurred which relate to federally mandated asbestos
inspections as required by the Asbestos Hazard Emergency Act of 1986
(AHERA). This bill would add asbestos inspections to the provisions
of the Mandated Services Act which already includes the
administrative costs associated with attendance reports, PEP test
reports, Regents Competency and Examination Programs.

JUSTIFICATION:
All schools, public and non-public are
under strict
federal mandates to inspect for asbestos and to eliminate any
conditions hazardous to health. While Chapter 262 of the Laws of 1988
provides $4 million for inspections, non-public schools are not
reimbursed for the expenses incurred in completing the necessary
reports and other paperwork associated with the mandates. This bill
would allow for state reimbursement to these costs under the same
section of law that provides for the costs of complying with other
mandates such as attendance reports, data system reports and several
reports associated with student examinations.

FISCAL IMPLICATION:
This bill is estimated, to have a cost of approximately $400,000.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
